objectDesc.extent:
ca. 260 mm x 166 mm (dimensions of all - size of leaves).
ca. 250 mm x 150 mm (dimensions of all - size of written space).

handDesc.summary: The four parts are copied by four main hands. Fols 1-61, Part 1 is copied by one scribe in square Anglo-Saxon minuscule datable to s. xi

hands.name: main text
hands.description: Fols 62-139v/5. A round, well executed script with insular letter forms.

characters.note: ð Prominent upperstroke with occasionally protruding strokes to the left.

hands.name: main text
hands.description: Fols 139v/6-149. A round, small script with prominent feet.

hands.name: annotations
hands.description: Extensive glosses, corrections and alterations by the

binding: Before 1621, Cotton bound Otho C. i with Otho C. i, Vol 1 (Wanley 1705, p. 212). Now the two parts are separate and Otho C. i has a nineteenth-century binding.

history.origin:
Part 1 has been associated with Canterbury and Exeter (Johnson and Rudolf 2010, p. 5).

Parts 2, 3 and 4 may have been copied in Worcester; see the discussion on the hand above, and also Budny's suggestions that fols 62-137 may have been made during the episcopy of Wulfstan II, Bishop of Worcester 1062-95 (Budny 1997, p. 625).
history.provenance: Parts 1, 2, 3 and 4 were probably in Worcester by 1060-1080. The corrections, glosses, marginal notes and running titles confirm that the four parts were available to readers in Worcester at the end of the eleventh century, for instance Coleman, and still read by the Tremulous Hand in the first half of the thirteenth-century.
history.acquisition:
Michael Lapworth, a fellow of All Souls College, Oxford, in 1562, could have owned the manuscript in 1593 as his name is written on fol. 31r. Atkins and Ker 1944 (p. 12) note that the Lapworth family was from Stowe in Warwickshire. It was acquired by Cotton sometime before 1621 when it was bound with British Library, Cotton Otho C. i, Vol 1 (see also British Library, Harley 6018).

Acquired by the British Museum along with the rest of the Cotton collection .

admin: Manuscript described by Orietta Da Rold with the assistance of Hollie Morgan and Sanne van der Schee (2010; 2013).
